ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

MASS RAPID TRANSIT SYSTEM
(Extension to Punggol)


    1. Dr Michael Lim Chun Leng asked the Minister for Communications whether there were any plans to extend the Mass Rapid Transit system to the Punggol ward of Cheng San GRC and, if so, what was the current status of such plans.

     The Minister for Communications (Mr Mah Bow Tan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government announced in August 1988 that it has given in-principle approval for the north-east sector MRT line. Punggol will be served by this line.

    However, the timing for the construction of this line will depend on HDB's programme for housing developments in the north-eastern sector. This is to ensure that there will be sufficient demand for the MRT when it is ready.

    The north-east sector MRT line is estimated to cost the Government $4.3 billion (1990 prices). This is a very heavy investment. The Government is prepared to bear the construction and capital costs. But there must be sufficient traffic to cover the operating cost, otherwise the operators will have to subsidise this line with revenue from its other lines. This will eventually lead to higher fares for all MRT users.

    The bulk of the housing developments in the north-east sector is due for implementation only after the year 2000. The Mass Rapid Transit Corporation (MRTC) can only firm up its plans nearer this date. Meanwhile, we are undertaking technical work to determine the route alignment for this line.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister for Communications whether there will be any station in the vicinity of Hougang Avenue 2 or Hougang Avenue 10. Is such a station being planned?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I said in my reply, the line itself is only

Column: 204

approved in principle. We have not actually made provision for any station along the route. This will depend to a large extent on what the housing developments are like.

     Dr Michael Lim Chun Leng (Cheng San GRC): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Minister for Communications, in view of the population of the north-eastern sector being substantially more than twice that of Woodlands New Town and yet a line has been laid to Woodlands New Town, this being a question that has been bothering a lot of the residents in my constituency and the detailed statistics having been brought up -

     Mr Speaker: Dr Lim, no speeches. Ask your question.

     Dr Michael Lim Chun Leng: Yes, I shall shorten it. Can the Minister kindly clarify whether the extension of the MRT line to Woodlands New Town is aimed primarily at encouraging Singaporeans to relocate there where there are about 70 blocks of unoccupied flats and hence priority was not given to the Punggol area and the rest of the north-eastern corridor?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, the truth of the matter is that the MRTC decided to extend its line to Woodlands before the north-east sector mainly because HDB firmed up its implementation plans for housing in Woodlands before the Hougang area.

    The other reason is the question of costs. The Woodlands line, according to the criteria for viability, is more likely to be viable under the present situation. It would take something like $1 billion to build the Woodlands line whereas it will cost four and a half times that to construct the north-east sector line.

     Dr Michael Lim Chun Leng: Sir, may I ask the Minister for Communications whether, since the Ministry has had some technical plans available for the extension of the MRT line, can he, in his wisdom, enlighten me as to what is the most likely date that I can look forward to for a line to my constituency at the north eastern area?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, it depends on many factors. I am afraid I am not able to give him a categorical answer. The

Column: 205

Ministry of National Development will first have to firm up its plans for housing in that sector before the trains can go there. I think the question should also be directed at the Minister for National Development.

     Dr Michael Lim Chun Leng: Sir, though my ardent and earnest plea on behalf of my residents in Punggol could not bring about an early solution to my request for an MRT line, in the interim, can the Minister kindly consider my humble request to increase the frequency of public transport services, such as bus services, to the nearest MRT station in Ang Mo Kio; this being a reasonable request and being in line with the Government's policy to encourage the use of public transport?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: It is a reasonable request and I will certainly ask the authorities concerned to look into it.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, since the Government has plans to bring the MRT line to Woodlands, I would like to ask the Minister whether there are also plans to extend this line to Johor Baru.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: The Government has indicated that when the line is extended to Woodlands, it will provide an opportunity for an extension, in one form or another, of a mass rapid transit system to Johor Baru. This of course would have to be undertaken jointly with the Malaysian authorities.

PUNGGOL WARD OF CHENG SAN GRC
(Building of bus interchange)


    2. Dr Michael Lim Chun Leng asked the Minister for Communications whether there were plans to build a bus interchange, and to increase the bus services in the Punggol ward of Cheng San GRC and, if so, what was the current status of these plans.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, there are plans to build a bus interchange at Hougang North to serve the north-eastern sector of the island which includes the Punggol ward of the Cheng San GRC.

Column: 206



    The bus interchange will be built in two phases. Phase I will be built starting in financial year 1992, ie, this year. When it is completed in 1993, there will be a total of eight trunk and two feeder bus services operating from there. The trunk services will link residents to major destinations like Orchard Road, Shenton Way and Chinatown and also to nearby HDB towns like Serangoon, Ang Mo Kio and Toa Payoh.

    Phase II of the interchange will be built later when the plan for the MRT is finalised, and for which I have given an answer just now.

     Dr Michael Lim Chun Leng: Sir, arising from the detailed analysis of the bus services by the grassroots leaders in my constituency and, in the interim, while awaiting for a new bus interchange, can the Minister kindly improve the seven trunk services and four feeder services in my area? I will give the detailed proposals to him later.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, I will be happy to receive those proposals and refer them to the relevant authorities.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, as the construction of the MRT line and a new bus interchange will take some time, will the Minister for Communications consider an interim measure to have a direct bus service from Upper Serangoon Road (on the Punggol side) to link to the town area in Bras Basah Road? There was a bus service before (Service No. 82) but it is now redirected to Hougang Avenue 10 and as a result, residents living in Hougang Avenue 7 -

     Mr Speaker: Mr Low, just ask your question.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: All right, Sir. I would like to know from the Minister whether or not he will consider having this bus service as an interim measure.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, the question of specific bus services that the Member for Hougang has raised, I would rather leave to the operators to answer. But, in general, there has been a conscious effort on the part of the bus operators to provide an adequate level of service, a minimum standard of service, from each of the new towns in Singapore. You

Column: 207

have to recognise that there are limits to the resources that are available to them and within these limits, they do try and make adequate provision for all bus services. If the Member wishes to put his request in writing to me, I will refer it, like all other requests, to the relevant authorities.

PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS

Debate on the Address
(Third Allotted Day)


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [13th January, 1992],

    'That the following Address in reply to the Speech of the President be agreed to:-

    "We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore, express our thanks to the President for the Speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the Opening of the First Session of this Parliament.".' - [Dr John Chen Seow Phun].

    Question again proposed.
12.42 pm

     Mr Ling How Doong (Bukit Gombak): Mr Speaker, Sir, I seek your indulgence, lest it be said that I will be harping on the same topic as my colleagues, Mr Chiam See Tong and Mr Cheo have touched on earlier. I am speaking on the deprivation of MPs' offices.

    Sir, at every election, it has been held out by the Government to the public at large that anybody who wants to take part in the election and on the successful contest of the election, he will be provided, inter alia, an MP allowance and also an MP's office.

    Sir, it is my submission, on this implied offer, that anyone who takes part

Column: 208

in an election is deemed to have accepted the offer. It therefore becomes a contract that the MP should be provided with an office.

    Another point is that, as my friend, Mr Cheo has mentioned yesterday, Opposition MPs have got only the MP's office to operate. We cannot make use of the community centres. Neither can we make use of the Residents' Committees' premises. I need not have to repeat again that we, as elected representatives of the people, are performing the function more than grassroots leaders. I urge that MPs should continue to be provided with premises.

    Sir, this ruling, in fact, affects the interest of every Member in this House but until now, I have yet to hear one single MP raising this issue. It is most telling, and I think the silence speaks volumes.

    I now move on to the topic of education. In education, the system leaves much to be desired. The Government's proposal is that only 25% of the independent school pupils will be funded and the average pupils from the non-independent schools will also be given another type of scholarship. However, in respect of the second type of scholarship, the number and the amount have not been spelt out. With the introduction of a scheme whereby 25% of the pupils from the independent schools are to be funded, it would appear that elitism has finally permeated the cradle and, to say the least, this is elitism at its worst.

    With the 25% of the students being funded, what about the 75% of those who are not funded? I am quite sure that quite a high proportion of this number are either from the lower or the middle income group. Imagine for a moment, Sir, a family who has got two children who are both in independent schools, would they afford the fees of $200 per child? Not forgetting, in Singapore, we have between 400,000 and 450,000 workers earning $1,000 a month, and after CPF deductions, the take-home pay is in the region of over $800. Furthermore, one half of the workers

Column: 209

among the 750,000, their income is only $800, and the take-home pay after CPF deductions is only $616. What I am asking is: what will the Government do to lighten the financial burden of these people? In fact, I would even suggest that it is near impossible for them to finance the children in the independent schools.

    Sir, we are not quarrelling, and while we agree that talented and gifted children should be given the opportunity to advance their potential, that should not be done at the expense of the average pupil or his parents whose taxes provide the scholarships given to the more able. All of you will agree with me that families of pupils in independent schools who are already benefitting from better facilities and teachers should be subject to a means test when applying for scholarships. In other words, the granting of scholarships to pupils in independent schools will be subject to a means test. If the parents' ability to pay for the fees is there, they should not be given. If it is a recognition of their academic performance, I would suggest that the school give them book prizes.

    Let us remember that at the last general elections, the People's Action Party promised the voters that every child would benefit from Edusave. Every one would start with $100 a year. The figure would gradually rise to $500 and this of course depends on the investment or the benefit derived from the Endowment Fund. It is also very clear now that with the creation of these two scholarships, this particular fund of $100 a year per child would accordingly be reduced. How much would the child get? Even before the introduction of these scholarships, it is only $100. Now perhaps the child may even get $50 a year. I do not know. It may be much less. I am urging that the Government should seriously consider this factor. One distinction ought to be drawn here. For tertiary education, one can understand that we grant scholarships based strictly on merit, because for tertiary education the scholarship is given to you and you

Column: 210

are bonded to the Government. You are to serve the Government in return. Whereas in the independent schools, there is no bonding at all. You are given the scholarship, after which you can decide whether to serve the Government or not.

    Under the present system, the children of millionaires who are accepted into independent schools will receive scholarship funds from the Government along with children of the less well-off families who are fortunate enough to be in the independent schools. As for the children from the less well-off families, they are not lucky enough to get a scholarship to the Government school and they will find that the Edusave of $100 per year to start with would be drastically reduced. And as I said earlier, the amount that is ultimately for the children of average intelligence would be very much less.

    It would appear that in Singapore there is no true democracy. All children are not born with equal opportunities. Those considered to be brighter are given more advantages than the average. The Government's elitist policy is to widen the differences already existing at birth. Those not up to the mark are to be denied the chance to fulfil their potential and are destined to a future as lowly paid menials to the elite.

    In respect of health care, Sir, I think the Government ought to be applauded for its policy to continue subsidising C and B2 class wards. However, I am urging the Government to seriously consider only to charge Singaporeans the running cost of the ward. It would appear to me that, as it stands now, the Government is in fact making money from the citizens of Singapore. To make money from one's own citizens in respect of health care is bad enough, and to make money at the misery of the citizens is worse.

    I will cite a few examples, Sir. In fact, I have checked with two hospitals in Singapore. For the B1 class, there is no subsidy at all. The B1 class in Singapore is a 4-bedded ward with air-conditioning. The Singapore General Hospital is

Column: 211

charging $170 per bed. Whereas in one well-known private hospital, for an air-conditioned 4-bedded ward, it is charging only $150. For another hospital which has only 2- and 3-bedded wards, they are charging only $160 per day. In comparison, the Singapore General Hospital has the highest ward charges compared to these two other hospitals. Sir, not forgetting that these two hospitals are investments by private individuals and companies who have sunk the money into the hospitals, and they are not sure that they will get any return. And yet they could charge $160 or $150 per day. How come the Singapore General Hospital is charging $170?

    When a private hospital can charge you $160 or $150, I am quite sure they make $70. They make 50% from the ward charges, in other words, leaving the running cost to about $70. Even based on this assumption, the Government should charge $70. But I would go further. The Government would be able to charge less than this, simply because for a Government hospital, the infrastructure, the buildings and all the equipment are purchased from the taxpayers' money. Therefore, the Government should consider this factor. For non-subsidised wards, the Government should charge only the running cost, not the amount which appears to be profitable.

    The next point, Sir, is that the Government should also ensure that kidney patients in Singapore are looked after. Every year, we have between 200 and 250 patients suffering from kidney ailments and they have got no one to turn to. And if your income is low, that is the end of you. Because dialysis treatment alone, unless you get a place like the National Kidney Foundation or whatever it is, it will be a crippling blow to most breadwinners of the family. So I urge the Government to consider helping these people by subsidising their treatment and supplying cyclosporin at affordable rates, if not free.

    In respect of Medifund, I am going to say that a certain aspect of the Medifund scheme is a cruel joke. It is a cruel joke.

Column: 212

It is supposed to be a safety net, but it is a net which is not big enough and it has holes. This safety net has got holes in it. If you want to utilise Medifund, it has to be decided not by doctors but by unqualified community leaders who, in addition to looking at the patient's actual medical condition, will also be looking into the wallet. Getting a grant from Medifund depends on how well the patient has paid his contributions in the past, and not on how sick he is. This is the criterion for the grant of Medifund. One has to consider the factor whether he has paid in the past, and not so much on how seriously ill he is.

    As regards access to this fund, the assessment should come from qualified people, not by our neighbourhood busybodies, because it will ultimately become an intrusion into the privacy of the patient. Imagine for a moment, a woman who suffers from breast cancer or cancer of the cervix and who needs surgery, or a senior citizen who requires colostomy for treatment of piles, he or she has to apply to the committee of the RC or community centre. Could you imagine for a moment the embarrassment? Because they are not qualified medical people and yet they are given the task to assess the eligibility of applicants to qualify for Medifund. Sir, this factor ought to be considered seriously by the Government.

    In respect of housing, the upgrading of HDB flats would be a tremendous burden, especially to those retirees, those in the low income group, as they have neither savings nor CPF and they will have no way to contribute towards the upgrading of their respective flats. In a way, the upgrading exercise is a bit of a joke. The Government and the Town Councils will have to contribute to the upgrading. But, in reality, it is the residents who pay all this, simply because, firstly, they are the taxpayers. Secondly, they pay their conservancy charges to the Town Council. So the Government contributes through the taxes of the people. The Town Councils contribute through the conservancy charges collected over the years. Thirdly, direct cash from the CPF. It therefore begs the question: what happens if a

Column: 213

person has no savings and no CPF? This problem would not have arisen had the Government actually built first quality flats. The fact that the Government is considering water-proofing the bathroom floors is an indication that the flats were constructed without water-proofing in mind. From the experience of my Town Council, we are now faced with the problem of spalling concrete from the roof and we have to carry out all the repairs now. Next door to us is the Princess Elizabeth Estate which was built in 1951 by the Singapore Improvement Trust (SIT). These flats have got no problem of this nature.

    Sir, the Government has announced that recruitment, promotion and management of civil service personnel would be delegated to the various ministries and departments. This is because central control means rigidity and an inability to cope with changing labour market conditions. These changes, I must admit, are welcome in principle, but I hope the Government will ensure an adequate review mechanism to ensure that the civil servants are protected from arbitrary personnel management decisions by their departmental superiors. Furthermore, with the wage scale becoming more flexible, there should be some standardisation of other benefits so as not to disadvantage the staff. Also, adequate arrangements should be put in place to ensure that the transfer of staff between ministry and department can easily take place. This treatment of all grades of staff is not just confined to the so-called high-flyers.

    Besides all these, the Government should also look into other reasons why it is not able to attract and retain staff. Perhaps, it is because this Government does not allow the civil servants sufficient scope for the exercise of initiative, career development and treat them like digits.

    Lastly, Sir, the hon. Member for Tanjong Pagar GRC, Mr Koo Tsai Kee, mentioned the other day (liangyao ku kou) - good medicine tastes

Column: 214

bitter. I am curious to know whether it will be (kujin ganlai).

     The Minister for Health (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Sir, I would like to respond to some of the remarks made by the Member for Bukit Gombak.

    Sir, firstly, I am glad he applauds the Government for continuing the subsidy for B2 and class C wards. I am also glad that he agrees that we should charge at least the running costs for the class A and B1 wards, being unsubsidised wards.

    As stated in the Presidential Address, we will continue to gradually increase the recovery rates for A and B1 wards, because at the present moment they are still being subsidised. So we will be doing that. I am glad that Mr Ling fully agrees with us.

    Sir, he has made some very simplistic statements about the pricing of the B1 beds in SGH versus the beds in the private hospitals. I agree with him that private hospitals are doing business and therefore they must make a profit. But obviously, although he is in the private sector, he does not understand the mechanism of pricing. Sir, there are such things as loss leaders in business; if not loss leaders, at least attractive packages to get people in through the front door. The pricing of hospital beds in private hospitals, unfortunately, is a very classical case of pricing low to get people in through the front door.

    Patients who go in to a private hospital pay between $150 and $170 only for the bed. That, unfortunately, is not what the patient actually ends up paying. If Mr Ling had taken the trouble to find out from his friends about the actual bill sizes for patients in private hospitals, he will find that the cost to the patient is not $170 but that the final bill size in private hospitals is routinely in excess of $600. This is only for the hospital portion of the service. It does not include the services of the doctors or the anaesthetists. Those are over and above what is payable.

    Sir, if the private hospitals are indeed cheaper than SGH, I can assure you that Singaporeans, being very, very careful

Column: 215

about value for money, would be flocking to the private hospitals and SGH would have a dearth of patients for the B1 wards. Unfortunately, the contrary is the truth, ie, in SGH, patients who want to go into the B1 wards, unfortunately, have to wait today for their beds because they are so popular. Surely, Singaporeans are no fools. If it is so much more expensive to go to SGH, they will speak with their wallets and with their feet.

    Sir, he has also mentioned about Medifund. He asked: how can we allow community leaders to determine who should receive subsidies from Medifund and allow the community leaders to make decisions on medical matters? Again, he has talked in a knee-jerked manner without first determining exactly what is the proposal. Again, a very simplistic approach to the discussion of the issue.

    Sir, the concept of Medifund is that the patients who find that they are unable to pay the fees for medical treatment can make a request for additional subsidies to be given through Medifund. The Government can take the easy way out by referring all these requests to the Ministry of Health. But we feel that by allowing community leaders to take part in this approval process, we will be able to bring the decision-making to a lower level and to a group of people who are likely to be more compassionate and who have a better feel of what is happening on the ground. So therefore the proposal to bring in community leaders into this process of determining who should be receiving the additional support from Medifund. Sir, they will in no way be involved in determining whether medical treatment should be given because they are in no position to make such decisions. So I hope that the Member for Bukit Gombak will take the discussions of issues in this House very seriously and do his basic research before coming here and making such simplistic statements.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, as I walked in just now the Member for

Column: 216

Bukit Gombak was commenting on the HDB upgrading programme. I think he should be aware, but if he is not aware, I would like now to make him aware that the upgrading programme is not compulsory. It requires 75% of the residents to agree, and those who do not agree have to go along. But if they cannot afford, they can get a loan from the HDB for their portion of the upgrading programme costs. And if they have no income, as he said, those who have retired, they need not even borrow. The amounts spent will be held against their flat and one of these days when they sell their flat, the amount will be recovered. But since he is so much against the upgrading programme, I want to assure the Member that we will leave his constituency entirely out of the upgrading programme.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng (Cheng San GRC): Sir, if you are now hard of hearing, I could understand because I was. I did not hear you when you called the Minister to speak, because sitting in front of the Member for Bukit Gombak while he was speaking, my ears are still ringing from his sound and fury - 90% sound and 10% fury. Perhaps I should make a request to you to change my seating position.

    Sir, I support the motion to thank the President for his Address. In this respect, I would like to applaud the Government for taking the first steps into the Next Lap. More so in the caring nature in which these steps are being taken. For if there ever was a central theme in the President's Address, it would be one of human resource development to level-up all Singaporeans, to as high a level as possible. The focus on education for a sound mind, health for a sound body and housing to provide quality homes for sound bodies and minds is, well, if I may say, sound.

    Earlier, Mr Chiam, the Member for Potong Pasir, asked in his speech, "What type of Singapore do we want?" Sir, it is a very good question but, unfortunately, he provided the wrong answers. Hopefully, my colleagues who spoke earlier have put him on the right path, so I will not belabour this point.

Column: 217

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng: Sir, I wish Mr Chiam would not interrupt when I am speaking.

The only problem is finding out what is the intelligent way to spend it. I think the next phase is not going to be so easy. I quote you a different person, Lester Thurow, Professor, MIT. He was here last year as a Lee Kuan Yew Visitor. He gave a lecture in NTU in July. I read you his conclusion:

    'It is important to understand that there are lots of economies in the world that basically reached the level of Singapore, and then have not been able to make the jump up into the developed world.'

So getting here, that is easy. Jump into developed status, that is hard. Then he goes on:

    'If you look at the world's wealthiest countries in 1870, ie, 120-130 years ago, and you compare them with the world's wealthiest countries today, only one industrial country in the world has made it into that club in 120 years: Japan. No other country in the face of the globe has done it; two or three natural resource countries that used to be on the list (Argentina, Chile and New Zealand) have dropped off the list; a couple of oil-wealthy countries like the United Arab Emirates and Kuwait have joined the list but the only industrial country to make it in 120 years is Japan. Of course, that tells you that it is not an easy thing to do. In some sense Singapore has the hard part ahead of it; and for that hard part, I think, the strategy has to be the human resource development strategy.'

    Which is absolutely right. Therefore, what do we do to make it? I think, firstly, we invest in education. Investing in education enables many more Singaporeans to upgrade, because if you learn, if you get skills, you can earn a living for yourself, far more than any welfare we can give you. This spreads the benefits of growth as widely as possible. In fact, this is the indirect way we can massage the distribution of income and make sure that we have relatively equal incomes in Singapore - by making sure that everybody with talent is able to get educated and therefore can earn a living, and that we do not have talented people, deprived of education, who are festering at the bottom of society, making revolution.

    If we want to become a high-tech society, a high-tech economy, then we need not just a few elite - inventors, scientists, research people - but also a large number of skilled workers. Because if you want to run a factory production line tip-top, just in time, zero defects,

Column: 253

then every worker must master mathematics, must understand how to operate the computerised equipment, must be able to program it, and when it has gone wrong, must be able to fix it himself, instead of standing around waiting for a supervisor to arrive.

    So, Mr Low Thia Khiang was right when he said we want to go for a large, broad base. In fact, that is one of the reasons why the Japanese make better cars than the US, because man for man, Japanese workers are better than the US workers. And team for team, multiply better, because not only are they individually powerful, but they work together as a whole.

    So education is important. It is one of the bread-and-butter issues. Some people say they cannot afford to go to university, they cannot afford this and the other. Let me show you some more numbers. Let us look at Figure 5A, to show you how education has spread in Singapore. In 1980, 70% of Singaporeans - we are talking about young Singaporeans aged 25 to 29 - had, at most, primary education. Upper secondary, 8%; university, 4%. If we talk about the general population, it would be much worse, because most of the older folks never went to school. In 1990, 25-29 year-old-cohort, primary or lower, down to 38%, reduced by one-third. Upper secondary, gone up to 13% from 8%, of which polytechnic was 7%, university, gone up from 4% to 8%. In fact, the number of graduates from university doubled, the number of graduates from the polytechnics greatly increased, those who left school before PSLE, down.

    If you look at the people who are going to university, just leaving school, I think that gives you an even faster, sharper story, because it takes 5-10 years from the time they leave school, finish their national service, enter the work force, and get counted in the census. So let us look at the people going to university. In 1981, 3,500. In 1991, 6,900. Polytechnic, more than double, 4,800 going to 10,200. VITB, nearly triple, 3,500

Column: 254

to 9,000. Remember, in 1981, you are talking about 50,000 people at the age of 18, roughly speaking. By 1991, the cohort had shrunk. You are talking about 42,000-43,000 people. So more are going to unversity on a smaller base.

    Who is going to university? The rich? Let us take a look at Figure 6 - Housing profile, who goes to university. One- and 2-room, that means the rentals, 2%; 3-room, that means lower middle class, 30%; 4-room, 21%; 5-room, 20%; private housing and so on, add up to 27%. If you compare this to the general population, it is not that different.

    Polytechnics, same pattern. 1- and 2-room, 3% of the polytechnic population; 3-room, 41%; 4-room, 29%. In other words, the university is a major avenue for social mobility. Affordability is no problem whatsoever for a young man or young woman going to university. If you have the ability, you make it. So we have indeed invested broadly in education to benefit many Singaporeans.

    But the President went further in his Speech. He said we should invest more in the talented. And I would say we should invest more in the talented, both as a nation and also as a Government. We can do this while looking after the needs of the average and the below average students. To say that everybody should get exactly the same from the Government, and nobody should get a single jot more, even if he has some special talent, that is populist, churlish, unwise. We will progress by encouraging every Singaporean to do his best, and by rewarding those who make their contributions.

    Why are Singaporeans reluctant to get ahead? Well, one possible reason, which is very strong in egalitarian societies like China or Russia, is that if you get ahead, everybody says, "There you are, you are a bloodsucker, an opportunist, one of these somehow disreputably rich people," rather than an entrepreneurial man who has got ahead by his energies and is bringing people along with him. If we want to get ahead, then we cannot level down. We have got to encourage individuals to get ahead to excel, and

Column: 255

then contribute to society, because some people are naturally more able than others and their contributions will benefit many more Singaporeans.

    No society is composed of zombies, every person is exactly the same as every other person. In every society you have a range of talents, those who are skilled academically, those who are skilled musically, those who are good entrepreneurs, businessmen, those who are administrators, those who are soldiers, those who are good sportsmen. It is a natural distribution of talents, it is part of the strength of the society. Societies which acknowledge this and exploit the varied talents and abilities of each one of its citizens, they do well. Those which forcibly prevent the more able from getting ahead, they fail.

    Let me give you some examples, because unless we look at the rest of the world and see how other people, other societies, solve their problems, I think when we discuss our own difficulties, we risk falling into a mood of navel contemplation, where you are so preoccupied with your own difficulties that you totally lose perspective on the reality.

    Take the British. They once had grammar schools, centres of academic excellence. Grammar schools were independent schools, not places like Eton and Harrow where the rich went, but independent schools where talented children from poor families could go and get a good education, and therefore make it into Oxford, Cambridge or LSE and succeed in life, people like Dennis Healey. But in the 1960s, because they had an egalitarian mood, Britain dismantled their grammar schools, so that everybody went into the comprehensive schools; good, bad, indifferent, they all went into the comprehensive schools, and all would be equal. It was such a strong mood that even their elite who went to places like Cambridge, after getting into Cambridge, they sought to remove privilege for outstanding academic excellence amongst themselves. If a person does brilliantly he gets a scholarship, but he

Column: 256

should enjoy no privileges whatsoever. Mute these differences. We will be happier if we are not so different.

    The only result Britain achieved was to lower standards in schools and in universities, and indeed in the industries and in the economy. Its centres of excellence have weakened, including famous institutions like Oxford and Cambridge, while their comprehensive schools are not better. They cannot even agree on universal, national, achievement tests, PSLE, 'O' levels. It cannot be settled.

    Cambridge once had one of the best economic faculties in the world. They were at the cutting edge. Now, you read the Economist, it says, "The Tale of Two Cambridges" - Cambridge, England, and Cambridge, Massachusetts in America. MIT and Harvard have the best faculties in economics in the world. What about Cambridge, England? Well, they say, sadly, somewhere around Pennsylvania State University. That is where it has gone. Of course, they have got other problems too, but this dilution of merit and systematic discrimination against achievement has not helped them whatsoever.

    The Communists went further. They tried to eliminate income differences by government order. They just legislated. It does not matter what you do. It does not matter what contribution you make, you get paid the same. The Chinese say, (tie fan wan, da guo fan). That is my contribution to the Chinese quotes for the day! But when it comes to areas which are important to them, where really outstanding performance is critical - you want rocket scientists, you want nuclear scientists, you want ballet dancers for the Bolshoi, you want chess grandmasters like Karpov and Kasparov, you want champion sportsmen, sportswomen, gymnasts, going to the Olympics - you do not start on the assumption that all men are created equal. You start knowing that men are created very unequal. Then you abandon your Communist rhetoric, talent spot the children very young and send the few who have outstanding potential into

Column: 257

special schools, special treatment, very best instruction and preparation, tutoring, pampering, so that in the end they excel, they do their country proud. And now that the Soviet Union has collapsed, they are not going to produce grandmasters any more, and you may well have a non-Soviet chess champion.

    So the Communists know that the propaganda is one thing, that undeniable reality of biology and of human society, that is different. You look at the Chinese. They are another egalitarian society. They established a special university programme for gifted children (an hui he fei) at the Chinese University of Science and Technology, (Zhong Guo Ke Ji Da Xue). They established it in 1978 by a special decree of the State Council. This was after Deng Xiaoping returned to power and propounded the philosophy that "if you want to catch a rat, it does not matter whether your cat is a white cat or a black cat. The question is whether it can catch the rat or not." So an egalitarian society established their gifted education programme. Every year from the whole of China, millions of children, they take 30 to 40 aged 14 to 15 - we put 100 into our GEP and we call them gifted - they go to Anhui, special classes, tutors and resources lavished on them. They study physics, electronics engineering, biology and system science. After they graduate, three-quarters go on to post-graduate programmes. QingHua University in Beijing, and JiaoTong University in Shanghai also make special arrangements to admit gifted children.

    So China, with 1.1 billion people, socialist, egalitarian ideology, finds it necessary to develop special gifted education programmes, and invest specially in their most talented people. We, with 3 million people, expect to do equally well without investing in our talent?

    Look at Hong Kong. Yes, their income distribution is more unequal than Singapore. They have tycoons, billionaires, multi-billionaires, shipping tycoons and so on. But would they be better off

Column: 258

without these billionaires, these talents who make their economy dynamic, vibrant, and much more so than Singapore's? If we can find people like that, like Steve Jobs, or like some of the Hong Kong entrepreneurs, then I think we should invest in their education, in their success. We get one top industrialist, he creates a multi-national corporation, a Singapore MNC, that means thousands of good jobs for Singaporeans. If it makes him a billionaire, good for him. It is also good for Singapore. And if this makes the statistics of income distribution look worse, so what. Are we worse off? Would you prefer him to be doing well some place else and prospering in some other part of the world instead? So it is better for us to have such people and help the country to prosper than not to have such people and let the country stagnate.

    If we want to build a tall pyramid of talent, then we must start from a broad base. This means incentives at all levels. You climb up each level, until eventually you reach the pinnacle. That is how you get chess grandmasters. Therefore, we must encourage many Singaporeans to strive, not just the few. Eventually, we will produce a top team, which is a strong one. But at the same time, which is very important, we will produce superior performance throughout the economy, and the country will prosper.

    This is why we support independent schools. This is why we are offering scholarships for independent schools. This is why we are also offering scholarships for non-independent Government secondary schools. We want the pinnacle of achievement, but we also want people who are going to neighbourhood schools, people who are average and above average, to feel that if they make the effort, if they do well, there is something in it for them. These are not medals which are beyond reach. We should create more centres of excellence. We should not dismantle those few which we have painfully created.

    In fact, this is not a new principle. It is long established, but we have put it in a

Column: 259

sharp form. Not everybody goes to junior college, or to the polytechnic, or to the university. Students who go to JC enjoy more subsidies than those who do not, because it is more expensive to educate in the JC. Those who go to the polytechnics and universities, they are subsidised even more. If you go to the university and if you study medicine, you enjoy a subsidy which is much, much larger than the total cost of training an arts graduate. Every year the Government gives scholarships to the most outstanding students, regardless of their family income. Then on graduation they come back, they serve the Government or the SAF or the Police. In fact, when the Government tries to get the university students to assume a slightly larger share of this very heavy burden, and up the school fees a little bit, there is a great outcry. So what are we talking about?

    Suppose we follow the opposite principle, propounded by Mr Low Thia Khiang and, I believe, today by Mr Ling How Doong, that the able should receive no more support than the less able. What should we do? Then logically speaking, if we want to be quite correct, we should remove all subsidies. We should not subsidise junior colleges, since not everybody can make it to JC. We should not subsidise the polytechnics or the universities. We should abolish Government scholarships. Then everybody pays full fees for higher education. That is being perfectly fair. Should we do that?

    So when we invest in the more able, in fact, we are equalising opportunities between richer and poorer Singaporeans. Look at it this way. For the student from a wealthy family, if the Government does not pay, he will go on father's scholarship, right? More and more are going on father's scholarship. They will get the education they can afford. You tell them they are not allowed to go to independent schools in Singapore. They can go to Australia, they can go to Britain, they can go to Canada. All the routes are open. All the calling cards are already available. And it is getting easier every year because the quality of our top

Column: 260

students is recognised around the world. But if you are a bright child from a poor family, where will you go? His potential will not be fully developed. So the end result will be less equality of opportunity and a more unequal outcome, not a more equal outcome.

    The President's Speech makes this implicit policy explicit. I think it is an important basis of our policies and one which we should not be ashamed about. It is right. It benefits all Singaporeans whether or not they get the scholarship, and we should do it. We are not doing this as a charity, out of the goodness of our heart, but as an investment. Those who benefit from society's support have a moral duty to contribute back to society. Most do. Of course, there are a few who say, "Well, I have got nothing out of NUS. I thoroughly detest the place. No sentiments for it whatsoever." I hope that does not extend to their sentiment for their country, and also despite that, they recognise the magnitude of the investment which the country has put in them and the hopes which we have invested in them, and will, nevertheless, play their part as good citizens. So the second thing to do is invest more in our more talented.

    Thirdly, we should generate incentives for people to work. We should not discourage efforts through welfare. You want to draw on the reserves, it is the surest route to bankruptcy. Mr Low Thia Khiang says "Reserves of $15,000 per head. Government has money but life is hard". I am told that it sounds even better in Teochew. The reserves are actually your money. First, it is the backing for the currency, guaranteeing the exchange rate of the Singapore dollar. You look at the rouble. You can have roubles by the fistful. You look at the Singapore dollar. Every day the exchange rate goes up and regularly MPs complain about that. Why does it go up? Because it is valuable, because it is backed, because people are confident that you can spend it outside of Singapore, you can get hard currency for it. Or you can spend it in Singapore on imports, you can pay for imports with it. You run down the reserves, you

Column: 261

depreciate the currency. It is a cheap way to finance a budget deficit.

    Secondly, the reserves are assets matching CPF balances. They guarantee the purchasing power of your savings. If you have money in CPF, CPF puts the money with the Government, the Government takes it and invests it overseas. How much are these CPF balances? As of October 1991, $45 billion. (zhengfu you quian, ren min ye you). $45 billion divided by 3 million Singaporeans, $15,000 per head. As Mr Low says, $15,000 per head reserves. That is your money. So Singaporeans are not poor.

    Thirdly, reserves are there in case of war or major mishap. We have no oil in the ground to pump. We have no uranium, diamonds, gold, opals, like the Australians to sell. Something goes wrong at GATT, the Americans cannot settle with the Europeans over agriculture, the package gets unravelled, they each go for their own trade bloc, we are out in the cold. The Japanese will invest in Europe to sell to Europe. They will invest in Mexico to sell to Nafta. They will invest in here to sell to whom? Where will you work? What will you depend on? You will depend on reserves. You want to spend them now? Well, we take the risk that we will have none when we need them.

    In fact, the temptation to raid reserves is quite a universal one. According to Fortune, in the United States lots of local government authorities have set up pension funds for their employees. They are obliged to pay in money to the pension funds every year so that when the employees retire they have money to take out to fund the pensions. But how much do you need to pay in to ensure that when you retire there is enough money? That depends on how profitable you declare your investments to be. So now that they are short of money, they are just declaring higher returns. Instead of earning a 2% rate of return, I shall declare that henceforth my pension funds will be better managed, 6% rate of return. So, therefore, I put less money

Column: 262

into the pension fund, and take the money out to spend on consumption. So when the local government employees retire, and if the 6% return was not realised, that is just too bad. The Singapore Government can do that too. But in Singapore we have created an Elected Presidency to make sure that these CPF savings are safe.

    Fourthly, if we want to prosper, harness free markets, do not subsidise consumption. There was a proposal yesterday to divert revenues from the COEs to subsidise bus fares. It sounds good. But is it wise? Whose money is the COE money? It is the Government's money. Whose money is the Government's money? It is yours. How do you want to spend it? If we put it into bus fares, you are going to distort the price signals, and the result will be inefficiency and waste.

    Let me explain. To run a bus economically you must have passenger load and they must be prepared to pay for the ride. Then you know you are not wasting your fuel, your bus driver's time, depreciation and so on. If you are going to subsidise it and say, "Well, it loses money. Let us run, never mind. Two passengers. That is all right. I will pay for the rest." You are wasting money, are you not? Because it is cheaper for you to let these two people go and ride a taxi and pay for their taxi, than to run the bus service, pay for the driver, fuel and all the massive overheads of the bus line. If you do this, people will live further from the MRT stations. They should cluster around MRT stations, in high density developments. But since you subsidise the bus lines, travel is cheap, people do not have to live so close by, they will live further away, and take the subsidised bus ride into the MRT station. When residents live further away, the property values near the MRT station will go down. Property values further away will go up. Since the property value is down, you will have uneconomic property development projects - low density developments. Land is cheap, we will build two-storeys instead of ten. It is waste. Wrong price signals lead to distortions, lead to inefficiencies.

Column: 263



    The worst examples are from the former Soviet Union. They used to subsidise for all their best reasons. Milk powder is good for babies. Milk powder was cheap. So people bought it. It was very cheap. They bought it by the ton and they fed pigs with it. Children's clothing was cheap. That should be subsidised. Everybody feels a soft spot for kids. So they bought it. They used it as rags to wash cars. These are real horror stories. If you continue with subsidies, in the end it becomes a massive drain on the state's revenues.

    I will read Yang Shangkun again. When a communist says this, you better take note:

    (In Mandarin): 'We are also trying to do this (housing plans) because in the past, everything is subsidised by the government. You pay only $1 to $2 rental. But we have to go along this road so that everybody owns his own house, otherwise the government cannot support it. If we have to repair the houses for our 1.1 billion people, how can we afford it?'

    (In English): All belonging to the state. Two rooms, one yuan per month. All from the government. Government must build; he enjoys it, payment nugatory. Therefore, you have to reform. The government cannot bear this burden. 1.1 billion people, and you have to build houses for all of them for free. Can you?

    So, if you accept that, then it is better the Government takes the COE and other revenues; look after them, invest them - in education, in infrastructure. The other way we can do it, which is a valid one, is to use these revenues as an opportunity to reduce other taxes progressively, so that people will decide for themselves how they want to spend the money, what they value most. Then people have a greater incentive to work hard and create more wealth. That is sensible. But, of course, if you say, just reduce taxes, no need to levy any new ones, that is not possible.

    Much has been said in the last couple of days about social costs, non-economic factors, getting increasingly important. Yes, economic progress does mean change. And change is unsettling, and change makes people worry. There are sometimes difficulties, like in health care.

Column: 264

We have a serious national problem in the long term which the Government has been candid to talk about and which we would like to resolve together with the people over the next few years. For example, we can help people to adjust through Medifund. But often the worries are totally unjustified and the social cost is only the discomfort of adjustment. Then we need to reassure people that all is well.

    Take time-based phone charges - tremendous alarm and unhappiness. Everybody worries that he is going to pay more. What are the figures? We have run it for a month. Price Waterhouse has gone through the December figures, and audited them. And do you know how many subscribers pay less? 73%, nearly three-quarters; even better than Telecom predicted. So the alarm was totally unnecessary. We, therefore, have to see change in perspective. And if we get agitated over every change, including those which we can take in our stride, then we are going to make slower progress.

    We have taken the hard-headed approach, but that is not because we are hard-hearted. In fact, we have taken the hard-headed approach because it is the more humane one. Because we invest more in the more able, therefore, all Singaporeans have progressed faster. Because we have minimal welfare benefits, therefore, we have few unemployed and destitute. Because we have depended on the free market, therefore, we have generated high growth and low income inequality. And because we have refused to subsidise buses, MRTs, and other public services, so these public services run efficiently, and even turn profits. And profits are good - not a dirty word.

    I am glad to see that many MPs in this debate have acknowledged that this is the right approach. We have not achieved economic success at the expense of other goals. Economic success is an important prerequisite to achieving other goals, including social and political objectives. We should bear this in mind if we wish to progress further.

Column: 281
